SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ______________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   There were plenty. Twenty or more.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?
   A dozen or more.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   In the winter once or twice a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?
   We always attended the church service.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   For parties it was invitation but at other times were welcome at any time.

   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

5. Generally for the evenings,
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
   Always welcome at any time.

   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?
   (that is, was the term to "teke petluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

6. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?
   Usually a lunch and tea or coffee.

7. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?
   Generally the family.

8. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?
   The ladies aid of the Church held sewing and quilting bees often.

   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

One spring there was a neighbor in the district sick and bed fast in seeding time so about a dozen farmers made a bee and put his crop in for him. Two cleaned and treated the grain and the others, some tilled the land and the rest drilled it in. If I remember right we completed it in less than three days. The neighbor was John Lott and he had a wife and family. This was back in 1911 or 12.

9. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were dances and cards for those who did not care to dance in the homes that were large enough.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

They were less in the homes after a hall was built in town and more central.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

No.
NEIGHBOUR VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the last five years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting?

There were plenty twenty or more, a dozen or less.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

In the winter once or twice a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

Generally for the evening.

What was the invitation to a meal served when people had come unexpectedly?

(That is, was the term to state publicly used, or just some other expression common?)

Always welcome at any time.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

Usually a lunch and tea or coffee.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place" generally the family.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

One spring there was a neighbor in the district sick and had fast in sending time so about a dozen farmers made a bee and put his crop in for him. The "bee" was not treated like a rain and the others came tillled three days. The neighbor was John Lott and he had a wife and family.

This was back in 1911 or 1912.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were dances and cards for those who did not care to dance in the homes that were large enough.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

They were less in the homes after a hall was built in town and more central.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times; every two weeks once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.) Give dates.

Till the hall was built the school was used for all social events. The seats could be moved to seat large crowds. It was used for church, plays, box socials, lodges and all public meetings. It was built in the fall of 1905.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?
   It was built about 1912 or 13.
   What material was it made of? How large was it?
   It is lumber construction with cement foundation. 30" X 50".
   Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?
It was built in town, in town and county, and township.
To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?
    Yes as far as I know.
    How were babies and small children provided for?
    There were always plenty of room.

    How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?
    The church built a shed (24 x 40) and they allowed it to be used at all times. At house parties in the county the farm stables were used. Schools all had stables.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?
    Pedro and Euphre.

    Was there card playing for a prize?
    Just small prizes as I remember.

    What dances were popular?
    Scotch, Square and Round dancing.

    Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.
    There may have been but none that I know of.

    Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
    There may have been some but not of my knowledge.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, "Pioneer Days," etc.)

Till the hall was built, the school was used for all social events. The seats could be moved to seat larger crowds. It was used for church, play, box socials, lodges and political meetings.

It was built in the fall of 1954.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

It was built about 1921 or 1925.

What material was used in the foundation? How large was it?

It is not known.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

It was built in town as a town hall, community and school house as a place for entertainment, dance, etc., but not for the school house as a place for school functions.

For what purpose was it built? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you have to travel to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

You can refer to the question above.

How were babies and small children provided for?

There were always plenty of rooms.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

The church built a stable (24 x 40) and they allowed it to be used at all times. At house parties in the country the term stables were used, although all had stables.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Pedro and Parcheesi.

Just small prizes as I remember.

Scotty, Square and Round Dancing.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings?

There may have been but none that I know of.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings?

There may have been some but not at my knowledge.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? There were never any attempt to have an upper crust or the Four Hundred Club in this district.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? There were two that took place with the early settlers. Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?
The Modern Woodmen of America. The Loyal Orange Lodge.
Give the date and reason for it being organized.
Woodmen in 1907 as a large number belonged in the States and had to send their dues back home so it made it more convenient and a number of new members wanted to join. The Orangemen for the same reason. They were both strong organizations for a long time.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?
Yes
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.
It was organized in 1906 or 07. Was started for the betterment of the Sask. Farmers. We were about to lose our rights to ship our wheat direct to the head of the lakes. This was one and there were numerous grain trade tricks we had to combat and our only way was organize.
Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?
I would think over eighty percent.
How many women belonged? How often did it meet?
Only a small number of ladies. Meetings were held twice a month in the winter season.
What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?
For entertainment we had a series of debates and each took their turn when called upon.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?
Yes
When was it organized?
In the early days but cannot give the year.
Approximately how many women belonged to it?
I would say perhaps forty at its peak of membership.
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. That attempt at formality, or "snark," do you remember in small towns, such as Butler, or even calling visits, calling visits? Villagers visited occasionally.

There were two that took place with him early settlers, telling how common they were.

13. Was there any other details of visiting parties etc., that you remember?

Tell us any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

14. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

The Modera Woodmen of America.

The Loyal Orange Lodge.

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

Woodmen in 1907 as a large number belonged in the States and had to send their dues back home so it made it more convenient and a number of our members wanted to join. The Orange men for the same reason. They were both strong organizations for a long time.

15. Was there a Basketmakers Grain Growers Local in your community?

Yes, Fall when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

It was organized in 1905 or 06 was started for the betterment of the local farmers. We were about to sell our rights direct to the head of the lake. This was one and there were numerous grain trade trouble we had to combat and our only way was organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

I would think over eighty percent.

How many women belonged?

Only a small number of ladies.

Meetings were held twice a month in the winter season.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

For entertainment we had a series of debates and each took their turn when called upon.

16. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district?

Yes.

When was it organized?

In the early days but cannot give the year.

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

I would say perhaps forty to fifty.

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1920, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes (who benefited from it, who joined, how people felt), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

I think it was in 1907 a Mr. Fisher from Regina came to Girvin and started a singing class. There was a couple lived in the district. They were from England and she was a trained singer and was instrumental in starting it. They chose a group from the class and trained them in a light Operetta, (The Bell of Barnstable,) which was a big success. We were invited all over where there was a hall and stage large enough to play it. There were about fifteen in the cast. Later years we had a dramatic club and would play nearly every winter. The twenty-fourth of May was our day for celebration and would finish the day with these plays. Some of the plays were The Private Secretary, Sallamy Trial, With in the Law, Smiling Through and several others. I have taken parts in a dozen plays.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Plays like I have mentioned.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

We used the school till the hall was built.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

No.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

No.

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Baseball in the summer and skating and Hockey in the winter.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
4.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, stating the name of each, (if known it was first organized), its activities, and property (if belonging to organization people), whether it had a district, or was centered in the town or village, and its relation to the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

I think it was in 1907 Mr. Fiskar came to Olean and started a singing class. There was a couple lived in the district. They chose a group of children and she was trained there over where there was a hall and stage large enough to play in. There were about 15-20 in the class, and we had a great time. We went out on Elbow nearly every winter. The "Country" folk of May was also played. We had a great time. The players were the Pravda Senatery Balling Team, which is the only balling through and several others. I have taken part in a danceplaya.

What games were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Play like I have mentioned.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

The first hockey club was organized in 1906. There were four teams in what was called the Northern Central League consisting of Lumsden, Craik, Davidson and Girvin. The Girvin team was Goal Clem. Reid, Defence Jack Young and Ed. Stewart, Rover H. Higgins, Center G. Vanstone, R. Wing Bert Vanstone and L. Wing Stan. Stewart. This team won the Hall Milling Co. Cup for three years in succession which gave them the right to keep it.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Hockey

What year? How long did it continue?

1906. Always have had a team.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Had a football team and a baseball team who played in leagues and at sport days in towns around the country.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Our first rink was built in 1906. Was used for skating and hockey. We had one of the best hockey teams in the early days. Curling rink was built in 1915 or 1916.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

We never had a covered skating rink. Our curling rink was built after 1914.
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

The first hockey club was organized in 1906. There were four teams in the early days:

Northern Central League consisting of Leonard O'Grady, Davidson and Girton. The first team was Goal: Glen Reid, Defence: Jack Young, Rover: H. Miller, Quarterback: T. Smith, R. Ming, Bert Vandenbosch and L. Wilson. This team won the Hall Milling Cup, Cap for Terry's, for the second year running.

How long did it continue?

1906.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1910, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

Had a foot ball team and a base ball team who played in league and at sport days in town around the country.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Our first rink was built in 1910, was used for skating and hockey. We had one of the best hockey teams in the early days. Our first indoor rink was built in 1915 or 1916.

We never had a covered skating rink. Our curling rink was built after 1914.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   About 1909 or 10.
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   No.
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   The young men of the community.
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).
   The twenty-fourth of May.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   We have always had a daily paper since we came to this country. The first was The Manitoba Free Press for ten or twelve years. We then switched to the Regina Leader Post as it was called in those days, as it had Saskatchewan news and our home to be. We also took our old home paper (The Haldimand Advocate) for years till we did not know the people back there.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
We brought a Dominion piano with us and still have it and is in excellent condition.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
Pianos and various instruments.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home-entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
I never played instrument myself but always enjoyed singing. I joined the first church choir in Girvin and the only one of the original one left. We had a large choir for years but has gradually faded away as the young people have not filled in the toll of the years.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

In the early days the young people went in for singing more than they do today in the rural country. When we went to a dance there was always an hour of singing if there was a piano in the house. I think it was that there a young couple who loved music and singing and lead the bunch.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
Any of the old southern songs, The Scotch songs of Harry Lauder, Some of the old eastern songs and the latest hits as it is today.
